awd_titl_txt: TC:  Small: Enemies from Within: Thwarting Sophisticated Insider Attacks in Wireless Networks
awd_abstract_narration: Wireless networks are inherently vulnerable to external and internal network attacks, due to the open nature of the wireless medium and the poor physical security of wireless devices. While external attacks can be neutralized through a combination of cryptography-based measures and robustness mechanisms, internal attacks, which are launched from compromised nodes, are much more sophisticated in nature. Insider adversaries exploit knowledge of network secrets (e.g., cryptographic keys and pseudo-random spreading codes) and protocol semantics to maximize their detrimental impact by selectively and adaptively targeting critical network functionalities. This project focuses on designing and evaluating secure protocols for thwarting sophisticated insider attacks of selective, adaptive, and cross-layer nature.  A unified adversarial model is considered in which selective jamming and/or dropping of high-value packets (e.g., control information) is used as the primary vehicle for denying network service. Defending wireless networks under this model is particularly challenging, because the adversary remains active for short periods of time and may adapt/modify his strategies on the fly. The impact of insider attacks on critical network functions such as end-to-end reliable data delivery and routing is quantified via extensive experimentation and modeling. Novel protocols are developed which detect ongoing attacks and identify compromised nodes in a timely manner. Project results will reinforce the resilience of wireless networks to denial-of-service attacks launched by insiders.  The proposed research is expected to have profound impacts on every wireless technology (e.g., WiFi, WSNs, MANETs, CRNs, Mesh, etc.), due to the generality of the addressed vulnerabilities.

por.por_cntn:
This main goal of this project was to analyze and mitigate sophisticated insider attacks, launched against wireless networks. Specifically, the PIs investigated adversaries that exploit knowledge of leaked cryptographic secrets and protocol specifics to attack critical network functions such as channel access, routing, and end-to-end reliable data delivery. Insider attacks were unified under one adversarial model in which selective jamming and/or dropping of “high-value” packets are the primary vehicle for attacking any layer or combination of layers of a wireless network.

This NSF award contributed to the education of five Ph.D. and one MS students. Moreover, two undergraduate students conducted independent research on project-related topics. This project led to the publication of eight journal articles and four conference papers, two Ph.D. dissertations, and one MS thesis. Results from this project were disseminated to the public via publications, invited presentations and keynotes, and briefings to industry affiliates. They were also integrated into curriculum development efforts.

Key project outcomes include the following:

Packet-hiding Methods for Averting Packet-Selective Jamming Attacks: The lower layers of the protocol stack were shown vulnerable to reactive jamming attacks that selectively target packets of high importance. Packet selectivity reduced the jammer’s energy expenditure by several orders of magnitude, compared to other jamming strategies. The attacks were enabled by packet classification during transmission based on static packet identifiers such as headers. To prevent packet classification before the end of a transmission, three packet-hiding methods were developed. These methods rely on a combination of cryptographic mechanisms, including commitment schemes and  cryptographic puzzles, with physical-layer parameters.

Intelligent Low-activity Jamming Techniques: A new class of physical-layer vulnerabilities related to frequency offset (FO) estimation in the widely adopted OFDM-based 802.11a standard was analyzed. FO estimation was shown corruptible if a jammer injected a properly designed jamming sequence during the preamble transmission. The idea is to design the jamming sequence with a similar structure to the actual preamble, but with modified amplitude and phase per jamming symbol. The superposition of the two signals at the receiver leads to a significant phase offset error that desynchronizes the transmitter-receiver pair. The attack involves several optimizations that minimize the jamming energy. It was found that it is sufficient to jam only a small part of the preamble (less than 0.5% of the frame duration) and still achieve 50% bit-error-rate. Several remedies were developed to counter this type of attack. Figure 1 shows an example of transmitting an image between two USRP devices, when a third USRP device launches a FO estimation jamming attack.

Mitigation of Selective Control-channel (CC) Jamming Attacks: In many wireless networks, the CC constitutes a single point of failure. To protect the CC from insider jamming attacks, a randomized distributed CC establishment scheme was developed. In this scheme, wireless nodes establish a common CC using a form of frequency hopping (FH), while following distinct FH sequences. This allows for unique identification of compromised nodes by nearby ones.  Figure 2 shows an example of the construction process of distinct FH sequences. Slots 2, 5, 6, 9, and 15 realize a common CC over several frequency bands, while the remaining slots are used for identification of compromised FH sequences.  The occurrence frequency of the CC is a design parameter that establishes a tradeoff between CC throughput and the delay until compromised sequences are identified.
